comments.body:
Can we rather wait with a polled query on the ns; and bigger timeout which fails, if it could not delete the ns in that time.
Also I am curious as to why this was not done earlier. (probably some specific reason @madhusudancs )

> Can we rather wait with a polled query on the ns; and bigger timeout which fails, if it could not delete the ns in that time.

@irfanurrehman What Shashi has now is actually the preferred method in kubernetes. 

> Also I am curious as to why this was not done earlier. (probably some specific reason @madhusudancs )

It's mostly for historic reasons. We wanted to be super careful about what we were deleting in the `federation-cluster` (now `federation-system`) namespace in the  pre-kubefed days. It just carried over to kubefed days.
@madhusudan thanks for the clarifications. Seems ok to me.

comments.body: Do we really need to do this separately at all. Shouldn't the for loop below in line 91 take care of this?

@madhusudancs, the for loop below does not include the `federation control plane` context and only iterates over federated clusters. may be some resource are leftover, if we just delete the federation api-server and controllermanager pods, but do not delete the objects in the fcp.
I see Ok, fair enough.

    # It is usually slower to remove a namespace because it involves
    # performing a cascading deletion of all the resources in the

comments.body: Can we just set it to this rather than defaulting?

Yeah, that's a good idea.

Right now we have a path where `FEDERATION_KUBE_CONTEXT` and `FEDERATION_NAME` might not be the same. The plan is to remove that path in 1.7. I will make the recommended change in the PR that removes the alternative path.
Could have used tee command here
please ignore this comment
silly bug, good catch

comments.body: I am not sure why change to use amd64 images?

This is somewhat subtle. In the previous/current mechanism, I used to build the hyperkube image on the fly and wouldn't prefix `-amd64`. Now that we are switching to using the real published images through our build system which uses the `name-<arch>` format we need this suffix. Also note, this doesn't hurt the existing system because of the change in line #297 below.
Doesn't seem to belong in this PR?

diffHunk:

    export FEDERATION_NAME="${FEDERATION_NAME:-federation}"
    export DNS_ZONE_NAME="${DNS_ZONE_NAME:-federation.example.}"  # See https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2606

    template="go run ${KUBE_ROOT}/federation/cluster/template.go"

comments.body:
There should be a loop here for all values in `KUBE_SERVER_PLATFORMS`, and the correct base image should be chosen.

Please use debian. You may see the base image values for all arches in the hyperkube Makefile

@madhusudancs There should be a loop here for all values in KUBE_SERVER_PLATFORMS, and the correct base image should be chosen.

like in `build/common.sh`

``` bash
for arch in "${KUBE_SERVER_PLATFORMS[@]##*/}"; do
  kube::log::status "Building hyperkube image for arch: ${arch}"
  REGISTRY="${KUBE_DOCKER_REGISTRY}" VERSION="${KUBE_DOCKER_IMAGE_TAG}" ARCH="${arch}" make -C cluster/images/hyperkube/ build
done
```

@luxas it doesn't make sense to add that loop here. These images are built on the fly,  only during development. It doesn't make sense to build the images for all the platforms while you are deploying for one of them. 

One thing we could do is build for $KUBE_ARCH. But I will do that in a follow up.

Okay, didn't get that this was only for development.

How about the release then? I assume these images should be released, and we have to have code for that also
We don't need special code for the release. We push the hyperkube images to gcr.io/google_containers.
What happens if we do not wait?
kubectl will fail because the DNS name for the ELB could not be resolved. I guess we could soak that up by retrying kubectl for a few minutes, but this seems more explicit.

comments.body: I am fine with removing this if and doing this polling for all cloud providers
GCE (for instance) attaches a Public IP directly to the loadbalancer, so there's nothing to poll as we already have the answer.
Yes. We dont need to run nslookup for GCE, but I would like to to remove that if condition if we can. Nothing wrong in running nslookup for GCE IP address?
